article.name: Google Chrome Phish Alert Button (PAB) Product Manual
article.title: Google Chrome Phish Alert Button (PAB) Product Manual
article.body:
The Phish Alert Button (PAB) Chrome Extension for Google Apps or Google Workspace gives your end-users the ability to report suspicious emails and empowers your employees to take an active role in managing the problem of phishing and other types of malicious emails. The tool can also provide your IT or risk management team with early warning of possible phishing attacks or malicious emails so they may take timely and effective actions to prevent security breaches or network compromise.

Paid Integration: If you have a paid account, the PAB will also track whether your users report our simulated phishing emails, so you can see which users successfully identify potentially malicious emails.

We encourage you to inform all of your users of this tool before making it accessible. To help inform your users, here are helpful resources that you can use to assist with the implementation of the PAB:

  • For admins - Best Practices: Phish Alert Button (PAB) Implementation
  • For end users - Phish Alert Button (PAB) in Gmail for Google Chrome Guide

For instructions on how to enable and configure your PAB in the admin portal, see our Phish Alert Button (PAB) Product Manual.

Installation Prerequisites

Below are some prerequisites for installing the Google Chrome PAB:

  • If you have not already whitelisted the Google Chrome PAB, please see the Whitelist the KnowBe4 Phish Alert Button (PAB) for Chrome article.
  • For the Chrome extension only, you must have the extension installed on a Windows, Mac, Linux, or Chrome operating system managed by Google Workspace.
  • End users must be logged in to Google Chrome and their Gmail account.
  • End users' profiles must be synced with Google Workspace while using Google Chrome.
  • You'll need the following Custom URL or Chrome App Extension ID:
    • Custom URL: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/knowbe4-phish-alert/hfokdlmjeppdmpbngjpnlnijogcecaop
    • Chrome App Extension ID: hfokdlmjeppdmpbngjpnlnijogcecaop
  • You must have administrative rights to your organization's Google Apps or Google Workspace account.
  • Chrome Management must be enabled for your domain or Organizational Units.
  • You must enable and configure your PAB in the KnowBe4 admin portal. You’ll also need to download the following file to begin installation:
    • phish_alert_configuration.json file

Cloud Policy Installation Method

If you are having trouble installing the Google PAB through the Chrome Web Store, you can also install the PAB through a cloud policy. Please note that this step will authorize the necessary permissions for the PAB to function on a domain-wide level so that your users aren't required to allow the permissions when they receive the Google PAB extension.

Important: Chrome Management must be enabled in order to deploy the Google Chrome Phish Alert Button. To learn how to enable Chrome management in Google Workspace, review Google's Turn on Chrome browser management article.
  1. In the Google Workspace Admin Console, go to Devices > Chrome > Apps & extensions > Users & browsers.
  2. Click the plus icon at the bottom of the page and select Add Chrome App or extension by ID.

  3. Provide the Extension ID found in step 7 of the Chrome Web Store Installation Method section below.
  4. Paste the JSON details into the Policy for extension field and click Save.

  5. Whitelist the PAB following the instructions listed in the Whitelist the KnowBe4 Phish Alert Button (PAB) for Chrome article.
  6. Go to Security > API Controls and select the Domain Wide Delegation option.

  7. Click Add New and paste the following Client ID and OAuth Scopes:

    Client ID:

    682409154127-0iivv9sj7c06t2niq3cb54l8tshdj0gq.apps.googleusercontent.com

    OAuth Scopes:

    https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.modify,
    https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.send,
    https://www.googleapis.com/auth/userinfo.profile
  8. Click Authorize.

  9. In the Apps & extensions window, click your top-level domain to edit the App settings for users at that domain.
    Tip:If your organization uses Google Groups for Business, you can select specific Groups for Business that you would like to force the PAB Chrome extension to.
  10. Under the Installation policy header, select Force Install for the domain you selected, or your selected organizational units (OUs).
  11. Click Save.

Chrome Web Store Installation Method

Follow the steps below for installing the Google Chrome PAB with the Chrome Web Store:

  1. Whitelist our application using Whitelist the KnowBe4 Phish Alert Button (PAB) for Chrome article. You will not be able to use the Google Chrome PAB unless you have whitelisted.
  2. Log in to your KnowBe4 account and download the phish_alert_configuration.json file from your Account Settings.

  3. Ensure you're logged in as an Admin to your organization's Google Apps or Google Workspace account. When you're in Gmail, click the top-right button to access your Admin area.

  4. Click the Admin icon to access your Google Workspace Admin area.

  5. Click Devices > Chrome > Apps & Extensions > Users & browsers.

  6. First, click the plus icon on the bottom right of your screen, then click the Add Chrome App or extension by ID button.

  7. On the Add Chrome app or extension by ID screen, enter the extension ID and then click Save.

    • Extension ID: hfokdlmjeppdmpbngjpnlnijogcecaop

  8. Click your top-level domain in the left-hand panel to edit the App settings for users at that domain. If you want to install the PAB Chrome extension for only specific organizational units (OUs), click that specific OU instead of your top-level domain.

  9. Click the drop-down menu next to the ID and select Force install. Force install will prompt your users to allow the PAB to be installed during their next Chrome restart with a pop-up window. Ensure you inform your users you'll be installing the PAB Extension, so they know to approve the install. If you would like a customizable email template you can use to inform your users about the PAB, check out our Best Practices: Phish Alert Button (PAB) Implementation article.

    Note:If you are installing on an OU, install the Phish Alert Button with the allow install on the top-level domain and the force install option on the OU.

  10. Click on the application name to open the settings menu. This menu will open on the right-hand side of your screen. Copy and paste the contents of your configuration file phish_alert_configuration.json into the Policy for extensions field of the settings.

How to Uninstall

Follow the steps below to uninstall the Google Chrome PAB:

  1. Ensure you're logged in as an admin to your organization's Google Apps or Google Workspace account. When you're in Gmail, you can click the top-right button to access your Admin area.

  2. Click the Admin icon to access your Google Workspace Admin area.

  3. Click Devices > Chrome > Apps & Extensions > Users & browsers.

  4. Click on the PAB Extension ID in your list of apps: hfokdlmjeppdmpbngjpnlnijogcecaop.

  5. Your settings will open on the right-hand side of your screen. Click the trash can icon to remove the app.

User Experience

Once the PAB add-in is installed, upon their next Chrome restart, your users will be prompted with a pop-up message to allow the KnowBe4 PAB app to access Gmail. They must click Allow on this pop-up message.

After allowing the PAB app, your users will see the PAB as an orange Phish Hook within Gmail.

A user can use the Phish Hook to report any email as a phishing email. The reported email will be moved to the user's Sent Items as a forwarded message and deleted from the user's Inbox. If the user incorrectly reported the email, they can retrieve it from their Deleted Items or Trash folder.

Note: Users cannot use the PAB to report multiple emails at once. However, if an email has multiple emails associated with it, ALL of the emails will be reported when you report the email.

To instruct your users on how to use the PAB, you can provide our Phish Alert Button (PAB) in Gmail for Google Chrome Guide article.

Note: The PAB uses Campaign Recipient ID (CRID) validation to detect whether or not an email that is marked with a training header is a simulated phishing email. If a message has a valid CRID and is reported for the first time (within the past hour) from the same account where the PAB was installed, it will be treated as simulated. A simulated message will be deleted and only shown as reported in the console instead of being forwarded to PhishER.

Additional Resources

Below are some additional resources about the Google Chrome PAB:

  • Multiple Phish Alert Button Instances (Multi-PAB): Chrome or Google Workspace
  • FAQ: Phish Alert Button (PAB)

images.alt:
The image displays a vertical column of six circular yellow User Interface (UI) buttons against a white background. Five buttons are uniform in size, while the lowest button is notably larger.

**UI Elements (Top to Bottom):**

1.  Standard button with a square outline icon.
2.  Standard button with a stylized globe/earth icon.
3.  **Targeted Button:** Standard button featuring a 3x3 grid icon (typically representing an App Drawer or Menu). This button is the focus of a large, orange directional arrow originating from the upper-left.
4.  Standard button with an icon resembling a briefcase or bag containing a play triangle (likely indicating an app store).
5.  Standard button with the Google Chrome browser logo icon.
6.  **Action Button:** Oversized button featuring a black plus sign (+) icon. A standard pointer cursor is positioned near the bottom edge of this button, indicating a potential interaction point.

The buttons feature black icons centered within bright yellow circles, each casting a subtle drop shadow onto the white canvas.
images.context: rong> icon at the bottom of the page and select Add Chrome App or extension by ID.

images.alt:
The image displays a configuration panel titled **Phish Alert**, containing settings for an extension or service.

**Header and Navigation:**
The top bar includes the title "Phish Alert" and action icons for **Delete** (trash can), **Export/Maximize**, and **Close**.

**Chrome Web Store Options:**
This section features a toggle switch labeled **Include in Chrome Web Store collection**. The switch is active (ON). A status indicator below the option reads **Locally applied** with a dropdown selector.

**Permissions and URL Access:**
This section manages allowed and blocked network resources.
1.  A dropdown selector is set to **Use default permissions for this organization**.
2.  Two dedicated text areas are present for host lists:
    *   **Blocked hosts** (Hint text: *One per line*).
    *   **Allowed hosts** (Hint text: *One per line; allowed hosts override blocked hosts*).
3.  A status line at the bottom of the section indicates **Inherited from Google default**.

**Policy for extensions:**
This section displays a large block of JSON configuration data, editable via a text area. An **Upload/Expand** icon (upward arrow) is present in the top right of the block.

Key fields visible in the policy structure include:
*   `"phishAlertService"`: Configuration object.
    *   `"logLevel"`: `"ERROR"`
    *   `"api_key"`: (Value masked)
    *   `"base"`: `"https://training-staging.knowbe4.com/api/v1/phishalert/"` (Service endpoint).
    *   `"icon_url"`: `"https://s3.amazonaws.com/staging.uploads.knowbe4.com/pab_uploads_prefix/pab_icon/.../icon_gmail_64x64.png"` (Resource path).
    *   `"endpoints"`: Configuration for internal service calls (`"forwardEmails"`, `"report"`, `"initialized"`).

**Footer:**
Below the policy block, the status **Locally applied** with a dropdown is shown again. A large yellow Floating Action Button (FAB) with a black plus (+) icon is fixed in the bottom right corner, suggesting an action to create or add a new configuration item.
images.context: e JSON details into the Policy for extension field and click Save.

images.alt:
This image displays a screenshot of the Google Admin Console interface, specifically the "API Controls" section within the "Security" menu.

**UI Context:**

*   **Header:** Displays "Admin" logo and a search bar labeled "Search for users, groups, settings, or devices."
*   **Navigation Panel (Left Sidebar):** Shows an expanded hierarchy leading to the current page:
    *   `Security`
    *   `Access and data control` (expanded)
    *   The selected sub-item is **API controls**.
*   **Breadcrumbs:** `Security > API Controls`.

**Main Content Area (API Controls):**

The page is titled "**API controls**" and contains introductory text: "Use these controls to manage the API access OAuth apps have to users' Google data." The content is organized into sections:

1.  **App access control:**
    *   Description: "Manage app access to users' Google data."
    *   Links: "Learn about app access controls," "Google Workspace Marketplace allowlist," and "Web and mobile apps list."
    *   **Overview (Data points):**
        *   0 restricted Google services
        *   18 unrestricted Google services
        *   0 apps pending review
        *   2 configured apps
        *   2 accessed apps
    *   Action Buttons (Blue uppercase text):
        *   **MANAGE GOOGLE SERVICES**
        *   **MANAGE APP ACCESS**

2.  **Settings (NEW):**
    *   Description: "Manage settings for user messages, unconfigured third-party apps, internal apps, and more." (This section is collapsed, indicated by a downward-facing chevron icon).

3.  **Domain wide delegation:**
    *   This section is specifically highlighted by a thick red arrow pointing to the title.
    *   Description: "Developers can register their web applications and other API clients with Google to enable access to data in Google services like Gmail. You can authorize these registered clients to access your user data without your users having to individually give consent or their passwords."
    *   Link: "Learn more"
    *   Action Button (Blue uppercase text): **MANAGE DOMAIN WIDE DELEGATION**
images.context: rong> > API Controls and select the Domain Wide Delegation option.

images.alt:
A screenshot displaying a section of a management console related to API configuration, titled **Domain wide delegation** (gray, large font).

Below the title is a description paragraph (truncated at the end): "Developers can register their web applications and other API clients with Google to enable access to data in Go[ogle]. [You] can authorize these registered clients to access your user data without your users having to individually give co[nsent]."

Following the description are two linked UI elements:
1. A standard hyperlink: **Learn more**.
2. A blue, capitalized action link: **MANAGE DOMAIN WIDE DELEGATION**.

An orange arrow overlay points directly at the **MANAGE DOMAIN WIDE DELEGATION** link, indicating it is the targeted action item. The background is white.

2.  **Overwrite Option:** Below the client ID field is an unchecked checkbox labeled "**Overwrite existing client ID**." This option includes a standard information icon (i) adjacent to the text.
3.  **Scope Input:** A placeholder for a secondary text input field is visible, reading "**OAuth scopes (comma-delimited)**" in a muted gray color.
4.  **Action Buttons:** The bottom right corner contains two action buttons: **CANCEL** and **AUTHORIZE**.
5.  **Highlight:** An orange/red arrow is superimposed on the image, pointing specifically to the **AUTHORIZE** button.

images.alt:
This screen captures the configuration settings for the "Phish Alert" feature, located under the "Account Integrations" menu in the left navigation pane.

**Context and Status:**
*   The overall environment shows "SAML Settings" are currently "Disabled" (indicated by a red pill).
*   The primary function, "Enable Phish Alert," is active (blue toggle).
*   A link for monitoring, "See PAB User Activity," is present.

**PAB Settings Panel (Settings Tab):**
*   **PAB Version:** Displays "Chrome PAB" as the selected version, with an adjacent "Set as Default" button.
*   **Input Fields:** Includes text fields for "Setting Name" and "License Key" (content is redacted/blurred).
*   **Email Format:** Allows selection between "EML" (selected) and "MSG."
*   **Non-Simulated Reporting:** Includes an input field for email addresses designated to "Send Non-Simulated Emails."
*   **Validation Toggle:** A gray toggle labeled "Limit CRID Validation" is available.
*   **Languages:** Configured to "+ English (United States) (Default)."

**Actions and Output:**
*   Configuration changes are saved via the primary blue button, "Save Phish Alert Settings."
*   At the bottom, a technical output section provides access to the configuration file required for deployment:
    *   **File Description:** "Chrome Extension PAB config file (phish\_alert\_configuration.json)."
    *   **Action Links:** "View Guide" and "Download" (indicated by a download icon).
images.context: ttps://support.knowbe4.com/hc/en-us/articles/208969608#ENABLING'>Account Settings.

The image displays a segment of a web application header and toolbar, focusing on navigation and user controls.

**Contextual UI Elements (Top Row):**
1.  A white input field leading to a blue button containing a white magnifying glass icon (Search).
2.  The primary targeted element is the **Application Launcher icon** (represented by a 3x3 grid of nine dots), highlighted by an orange circle. An orange arrow and the instructional text "Click here" point directly to this icon.
3.  To the right of the Application Launcher are the **Notification icon** (bell) and the **User Profile icon** (a green circle containing the letter "K").

images.alt:
This image displays a section of the Google Workspace Application Launcher (also known as the "Waffle menu") modal window.

**UI Context:** The upper edge shows a thin navigation bar containing system icons (Notification Bell, Hourglass/Task, Help/Question Mark, and the 3x3 grid App Launcher toggle).

**Content Grid:** The main area is a grid layout of application icons and corresponding text labels, arranged in columns of three. Visible applications include:
*   **Row 1:** Account, Gmail, Drive
*   **Row 2:** Docs, Sheets, Slides
*   **Row 3:** Calendar, Chat, Meet
*   **Row 4 (Partial):** Sites, Contacts, Admin

**Targeted Element:** The final visible element in the third column of the fourth row is highlighted.
*   **Icon:** A blue and white stylized hexagonal structure (representing administration/settings).
*   **Label:** **Admin**
*   **Visual Emphasis:** This specific element is enclosed within a thin, red rectangular boundary box. A thick, red arrow originating from the right edge of the frame points directly at the bounded **Admin** icon, indicating the required selection.

This image captures the **Apps & Extensions** management view within a Google Admin interface, specifically focused on Chrome devices/browsers.

**Overall Context:** The user is navigating through **Devices > Chrome > Apps & extensions**.

**UI Elements and Navigation:**

1.  **Header:** Displays the product name "Admin" and a global search bar labeled "Search for users, groups, settings, or devices".
2.  **Breadcrumbs:** Located above the main content area, showing the path: `Devices > Chrome > Apps & extensions`.
3.  **Left Navigation Pane:**
    *   **Devices** is expanded and highlighted.
    *   **Chrome** (with a dropdown arrow) is expanded.
    *   **Apps & extensions** is the currently selected and highlighted sub-menu item.
    *   Other visible sub-menu items under Chrome include Setup guide, Devices, Enrollment tokens, Settings, Web capabilities, and Connectors.
4.  **Main Content Area (Apps & Extensions):**
    *   **Title:** "Apps & Extensions".
    *   **Contextual Note:** A gray text box states, "Group and organizational unit selection is unavailable in this view."
    *   **Action Bar:** Contains an "Overview" tab (currently selected/blue underlined) and a "Users & browsers" tab (highlighted by a red box/arrow).
    *   **Search/Filter:** A button/input labeled "+ Search or add a filter".
    *   **App List:** Displays two columns: "App" and "Installation policy".
        *   **Row 1:** App icon (fishing hook), name "Phish Alert Button", policy "Force installed in [blurred text]".
        *   **Row 2:** App icon (Python logo), name "Python Shell", policy "Recommended in [blurred text]".

**Highlighted Elements (Red Boxes/Arrows):**

*   An arrow points to the selected sub-menu item: **Apps & extensions**.
*   An arrow points to the parent navigation item: **Devices**.
*   A box highlights the currently focused device type: **Chrome**.
*   An arrow and box highlight the alternative tab view: **Users & browsers**.

This image displays a dialog box, titled in a blue header bar as **"Add Chrome app or extension by ID"**.

The content section provides explanatory text: "Chrome apps and extensions can also be added by specifying the ID. If it is outside the Chrome Web Store, you must also specify the URL where the extension is hosted."

Below the descriptive text is an input field, labeled **"Extension ID"** in blue text. The field is populated with the example ID: **"hfokdlmjeppdmpbngjpnlnijogcecaop"**.

Under the input field is a dropdown selector labeled **"From the Chrome Web Store"**, accompanied by a downward-pointing triangle icon, suggesting a predefined hosting option.

The bottom of the dialog box features two action buttons, aligned to the right: **"CANCEL"** (black text) and **"SAVE"** (blue text).

images.alt:
This image displays a configuration interface, likely for managing enterprise device policies related to Chrome apps and extensions. The interface is organized into two primary columns: "App" (left) and "Installation policy" (right).

**Global Installation Policy:**
The top section defines a global policy for non-listed applications.
*   **Policy Name:** "Allow users to install other apps & extensions"
*   **Current Setting:** "Allow other apps & extensions from the Chrome Web Store only" (Displayed in a dropdown selector).
*   **Source/Status:** "Inherited from Google default"

**App-Specific Policies (Rows):**
Below the global setting, a list specifies override policies for individual applications or extensions. Each row contains:

1.  **App Identifier (Left Column):** Displays the app's icon, the human-readable name, and the unique, long alphanumeric extension ID (prefixed by a generic extension icon).
2.  **Installation Policy (Right Column):** Displays the specific installation rule for that app, presented in a configurable dropdown, and the policy source status.

**Listed Applications and Configuration Status:**

| Application/Extension | ID (Partial) | Installation Policy | Policy Source |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Google Drive | `apdfllckaahabafndb...` | Allow install | Locally added |
| OneLogin for Google Chrome | `ioalpmibngobedobkm...` | **Force install** | Locally added |
| `hfokdlmjcppdpmpbng...` | (Same as name) | Allow install | Locally added |
| uBlock Origin | `cjpalhdlnbpaflamej...` | Default | Locally added |
| Python Shell | `gdiimmpmdoofmahln...` | Default | Locally added |

A standard black mouse cursor, positioned in the lower-right section of the display, indicates an interactive element on the screen.
images.context: on the top-level domain and the force install option on the OU.

images.alt:
This image is a screenshot of the **Google Admin console**, specifically navigating to **Device management > Chrome > Apps & extensions**. It illustrates the configuration process for a specific Chrome extension.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   **Header:** `Device management > Chrome > Apps & extensions`.
*   **General Policy:** "Allow users to install other apps & extensions" is configured (set to "Allow other apps & extensions from the Chrome Web Store only").

**List View (Left Panel):**
*   A list of installed applications and extensions is displayed (e.g., Google Drive, OneLogin for Google Chrome, uBlock Origin).
*   The extension with the ID `hfokdlmjeppdmpbngjpnlnijogcecaop` is selected, highlighted in blue. Its **Installation policy** is set to **Allow install** ("Locally added").
*   An orange callout box indicates that selecting this row (or implied action) will **"open the settings."**

**Configuration Panel (Right Panel) for the Selected Extension:**
*   The panel title matches the selected extension ID.
*   **Chrome Web Store options:** Contains the setting "Include in Chrome Web Store collection," which is toggled **off**.
*   **Permissions and URL access:** Set to "Use default permissions for this organization."
*   **Policy for extensions:** This section features a text input field labeled **"Enter a JSON value."**
*   A second orange callout box directs the user to **"Copy and paste the JSON file contents here"** into the JSON policy input field, indicating where granular, advanced configuration data must be entered.
images.context: ation.json into the Policy for extensions field of the settings.

images.alt:
This image displays the "Apps & extensions" configuration page within an "Admin" panel, specifically focused on **Chrome** devices.

**UI Structure and Navigation:**

1.  **Top Bar:** Contains the "Admin" logo and a search bar labeled "Search for users, groups, settings, or devices."
2.  **Navigation Rail (Left Sidebar):**
    *   The primary section currently expanded and highlighted is **Devices**.
    *   Under Devices, the **Chrome** section is expanded.
    *   The currently active page, highlighted in blue, is **Apps & extensions**.
3.  **Breadcrumbs (Above Content Area):** Shows the path: `Devices > Chrome > Apps & extensions`.
4.  **Content Area Title:** The main header is **Apps & Extensions**.
5.  **Contextual Note:** A gray box contains the text: "Group and organizational unit selection is unavailable in this view."
6.  **Tab Navigation (Above Content):** Contains two tabs: **Overview** (selected/active) and **Users & browsers** (highlighted by a red box/arrow).
7.  **Action Bar:** Includes a `+ Search or add a filter` button and a back arrow icon.

**Content Details (Apps List):**

The content area displays a list of two applications/extensions with associated installation policies:

| App | Installation Policy |
| :--- | :--- |
| Phish Alert Button (Icon: Orange fish hook) | Force installed in [blurred context] |

*(Note: Red arrows and boxes are annotations overlaid on the image, used to highlight the **Apps & extensions** navigation link and the **Users & browsers** tab, indicating key areas of interaction or context.)*
images.context: Click Devices > Chrome > Apps & Extensions > Users & browsers.

images.alt:
This image captures the Google Admin console interface for managing Chrome Apps & Extensions.

**Context and Navigation:**
The user is viewing the **Apps & extensions** section under **Devices > Chrome**. The active tab is **Users & browsers**, managing applications sourced from the Chrome Web Store.

**App List and Selection:**
The application list displays managed extensions. The extension **"Phish Alert Button"** (identified by the icon of an orange fishing hook and the extension ID `hfokdlmjeppdmpbngjpnlnijogcecaop`) is selected and highlighted. The configured **Installation policy** for this extension is **"Force install"**.

**Configuration Panel (Right Sidebar):**
A configuration panel for the selected "Phish Alert Button" is open on the right.

*   **Header Controls:** The panel header shows the extension name and includes action buttons for **Delete** (Trash Can icon, emphasized by a red arrow), full-screen view, and close (X).
*   **Key Settings:**
    *   **Installation policy:** Confirmed as **Force install**.
    *   **Incognito mode:** Set to **"Extension is mandatory for Incognito"** (toggle enabled).
    *   **Version pinning:** Shows status text: "The version pinning is not supported for this Chrome app or extension."
    *   **Chrome Web Store options:** "Include in Chrome Web Store Recommended" is disabled.
    *   **Permissions and URL access:** Set to **"Allow all permissions"**.
images.context: Click the trash can icon to remove the app.

images.alt:
This image displays a standard Google OAuth permissions screen requesting user authorization for a third-party application.

**Branding and Context:**
The interface features the Google logo in the top left corner, centered on a white background.

**Application Identity and Request:**
The application, identified as **"KnowBe4 Phish Alert,"** is centered below two application-specific icons (a user silhouette and an envelope with a fishing hook). The prompt reads: "KnowBe4 Phish Alert would like to:"

**Requested Permissions (Scopes):**
Two specific permissions are listed, each accompanied by a service icon (Gmail/Google) and an information icon (i):

1.  **View and modify but not delete your email** (Associated with the red Gmail icon).
2.  **Send email on your behalf** (Associated with the blue Google 'g' icon).

**Disclosure and Footer:**
A mandatory disclosure statement precedes the action buttons, detailing data usage: "By clicking Allow, you allow this app and Google to use your information in accordance with their respective privacy policies. You can change this and other Account Permissions at any time." Links are provided for "privacy policies" and "Account Permissions."

**Action Buttons:**
The user is presented with two options in the lower right corner:
1.  **Deny** (Secondary button, grey border).
2.  **Allow** (Primary action button, solid blue highlight).
images.context: >After allowing the PAB app, your users will see the PAB as an orange Phish Hook within Gmail.

images.alt:
This image captures the top action bar and message header of an email client interface.

**UI Elements and Actions (Left to Right):**

1.  **Back Arrow Button:** A rectangular, light gray button containing a left-facing arrow icon (representing the action to return or exit the current view).
2.  **Archive Button:** An icon button showing a downward-facing arrow above a rectangle (Archive function).
3.  **Report Spam/Abuse Button:** An icon button featuring an exclamation mark within a hexagon or stop sign shape.
4.  **Delete Button:** An icon button depicting a trash can icon.
5.  **Move to Folder Dropdown:** An icon button showing a folder, followed by a small downward-pointing arrow, indicating a dropdown menu for organization.
6.  **Tag/Label Button:** An icon button showing a price tag/label icon.
7.  **Phish Alert Button:** A button featuring an orange fish hook icon. The cursor (a standard pointer) is positioned over this button. A black tooltip labeled "**Phish Alert**" is displayed directly beneath the icon, confirming the button's function. This button and its tooltip are highlighted by an orange elliptical overlay.
8.  **More Dropdown:** A button labeled "**More**" followed by a small downward-pointing arrow.

**Contextual Text:**

*   Below the action bar, the subject line of the open message is visible: "**Tips for using your new inbox**".
*   To the right of the subject line, a gray label tag shows "**Inbox**" followed by an 'x' icon, indicating the message's current location and the option to remove the label.
